Originally slated for ten o'clock A-M on sixteenth september two thousand and twenty four, it's already been rescheduled thrice, tentatively landing on seventeenth september two thousand and twenty four at "somewhere after lunch".

unnormalised: And let's not forget the ubiquitous "urgent" requests. Every task, regardless of its actual importance, magically transforms into a top priority requiring immediate attention. You might diligently block out your calendar for a focused project on 20/09/2024, from 2:00 PM to 5:00 PM, only to have your boss stroll by at 2:05 PM with a "small favor" that eats up the entire afternoon. Suddenly, your meticulously planned schedule resembles a crumpled piece of paper, tossed aside by the winds of corporate chaos.

unnormalised: The Indian Standard Time (IST) operates on its own unique wavelength. A 3:00 PM deadline might as well be a suggestion for sometime between 3:00 PM and "before the end of the day". This temporal flexibility can be both frustrating and oddly liberating. Need to fudge a timesheet? Just embrace the IST spirit and generously round up your hours. After all, who's going to argue with the clock when it's already operating on a different plane of existence?

unnormalised: Then there's the "chai break", an institution so sacred that it transcends mere scheduling. Meetings will be paused, deadlines will be overlooked, and entire departments will grind to a halt for that sweet, milky nectar of productivity. Try scheduling anything between 4:00 PM and 4:30 PM, and you'll be met with blank stares and whispered protests. The chai break is inviolable, a cornerstone of Indian office culture that even the strictest project manager wouldn't dare disrupt.
